name.text: Appropriate row operation

questiontext.text: For this linear system @d\begin{array}{rcrcrcr} 3x &+ &2y &- &z &= &4\\ x &- &y &+&z &= &0\\ 5x & & &+&z &= &-1/2\\ & &y &- &4z&= &9 \end{array}@d what is the row operation that will, in one step, use the first row to eliminate the @ix@i in the third row?

feedback.text: Scale the first row to offset the leading entry in the third row.
The question is to eliminate in the third row

name.text: Find a linear combination of linear combintations

answer.text: The combintation is not defined since the parentheses aren't matched.

name.text: Find the canonical representative of the row-equivalence class of this matrix.

questiontext.text:
Find the canonical representative of the row equivalence class of this matrix.

@d\begin{pmatrix} 1 &3 &-1\\ 2 &2 &0\\ 3 &1 &4 \end{pmatrix}@d

answer.text: There is no representative of this class.

name.text: Find the echelon form of this matrix.

questiontext.text:
Find the echelon form of this matrix

@d\begin{pmatrix} 1 &0 &3 &1\\ 3 &0 &1 &2\\ 6 &2 &-3 &0 \end{pmatrix}@d

name.text: Find the set of solutions to the associated homogeneous system

questiontext.text:
Find the set of solutions to the associated homogeneous system.

@d\begin{array}{rcrcrcr} x &+ &2y & & &= &-1\\ & &3y &+ &z &= &1\\ -x &+ &y &+ &2z &= &0 \end{array}@d

generalfeedback.text: You could find the associated linear system and then apply Gauss's Method.

name.text: Identify the equation of the line through two points

questiontext.text: Find the line through the two points @i(1,4)@i and @i(2,3)@i.

generalfeedback.text: Find the direction vector through the two.

name.text: Identify the equation of the plane through three points

questiontext.text: Identify the equation of the plane through the three points @i(1,1,2)@i, @i(0,-1,3)@i, and @i(3,1,3)@i

name.text: Parametrize solution set four unknowns

questiontext.text:
Paramatrize the solution set of this system.

@d\begin{array}{rcrcrcrcr} x &+ &y &+ &w &= &1\\ 2x &- &y &+ &2z &= &0 \end{array}@d

Express the answer in vector notation.

name.text: Parametrize solution set three unknowns

questiontext.text:
Paramatrize the solution set of this linear system.

@d\begin{array}{rcrcrcr} x &+ &y &+ &2z &= &4\\ x &+ &2y &- &z &= &2 \end{array}@d

name.text: Vector sum in the space of quadratic polynomials

questiontext.text:
In the vector space of quadratic polynomials what is the coefficient of @ix@i in this combination?

@d3(x^2-3x+4)-2(2x^2+1)+(-x^2+2x)@d

name.text: Which variables are leading entries

questiontext.text: @d\begin{array}{rcrcrcrcr} 2x &- &y &+ &z &- &8w &= &2\\ & & & &4z & & &= &0 \end{array}@d

name.text: Find the angle between these two

questiontext.text:
Find the angle between these two vectors, in radians and to two decimal places.

@d\begin{pmatrix} 1\\ 1\\ 4\end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} -2\\ 0\\ 1\end{pmatrix}@d

name.text: Find the dot product of these two vectors

questiontext.text:
Find the dot product of these two vectors.

@d\begin{pmatrix} -1\\ 4\\ 2\end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} -3\\ 0\\ 2\end{pmatrix} @d

name.text: One value of solution of linear system

questiontext.text: What is the value of @iz@i in the solution of this linear system?@d\begin{array}{rcrcrcr} x &- &y &+ &2z &= &1\\ 2x &- &y &+ &z &= &1\\ x & & &+ &3z &= &4 \end{array}@d

name.text: One value of solution of linear system

questiontext.text: What is the value of @iy@i in the solution of this linear system?@d\begin{array}{rcrcrcr} x &- &y &+ &2z &= &1\\ 2x &- &y &+ &z &= &1\\ x & & &+ &3z &= &4 \end{array}@d

name.text: what is the 1,3 entry when this matrix is in reduced echelon form

questiontext.text:
What is the @i1,3@i entry when this matrix is in reduced echelon form?

@d\begin{pmatrix} 1 &1 &1 &4\\ 2 &2 &-1 &4 \end{pmatrix}@d

name.text: What is the 2,3 entry in the reduced echelon form of this matrix?

questiontext.text:
What is the @i2,3@i entry in the reduced echelon form of this matrix?

@d\begin{pmatrix} 1 &2 &0 &1\\ 3 &0 &1 &1\\ 2 &2 &1 &0 \end{pmatrix}@d

name.text: What value must the variable have to make the two orthogonal

questiontext.text:
What value must @ix@i have for the two to be orthogonal?

@d\begin{pmatrix} x\\ 2\end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} -1\\ 3\end{pmatrix}@d

name.text: Find matrix entry from row and column indices

questiontext.text:
What is @ia_{2,3}@i?

@dA=\begin{pmatrix} 2 &1 &4\\ 0 &-1 &5\\ 9 &1/2 &6 \end{pmatrix}@d

name.text: Find second entry in the particualr solution

questiontext.text:
This is the solution set of a linear system. 

@d\{ \begin{pmatrix} 0\\ 2\\ -1\end{pmatrix} +\begin{pmatrix} 1\\ 1/2\\ 4\end{pmatrix}z +\begin{pmatrix} 3\\ 0\\ -3\end{pmatrix}w | w,z\in\mathbb{R} \} @d

Find the second entry in the particular solution vector.

name.text: One variable of solution of simple linear system

questiontext.text: What is the value of @ix@i in the solution of this linear system?@d\begin{array}{rcrcr} x &+ &y &= &1\\ x &- &y &= &0 \end{array}@d

hint.text: Add the first row to the second.

name.text: Third component of vector combination

questiontext.text:
What is the third component of the result of this combination?

@d2\begin{pmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ 3\end{pmatrix} -\begin{pmatrix} -1\\ 4\\ 2\end{pmatrix} +0.5\begin{pmatrix} 6\\ -8\\ 0\end{pmatrix}@d

name.text: What is the second component of this combination of vectors?

questiontext.text:
What is the second component of this combination?

@d3\begin{pmatrix} -5\\ -2\\ 0\end{pmatrix} -4\begin{pmatrix} 1\\ 1\\ 7\end{pmatrix} +2\begin{pmatrix} -2\\ 8\\ 0\end{pmatrix}@d

name.text: A reduced echelon form matrix has a leading one in each row

questiontext.text: A reduced echelon form matrix has a @i1@i leading each row.

name.text: A vector space must have infinitely many elements

questiontext.text: A vector space must have infinitely many elements.

feedback.text: A vector space can consist of just the zero vector, and so have exactly one element.

name.text: Does the system have a unique solution?

questiontext.text: This system has a unique solution.@d\begin{array}{rcrcrcr} x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0\\ 2x &+ &y &- &2z &= &2\\ x &+ &2y &+ &5z &= &-1 \end{array}@d

feedback.text: Bring the system to echelon form and notice the impossibility.

name.text: Does the system have a unique solution? Yes

questiontext.text: This system has a unique solution.@d\begin{array}{rcrcrcr} x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0\\ 2x &+ &y &- &2z &= &2\\ x &+ &2y &+ &5z &= &-2 \end{array}@d

feedback.text: Bring the system to echelon form and note that you could apply back-substitution.

name.text: Length of a vector

questiontext.text:
This vector has length greater than @i4@i.

@d\begin{pmatrix} 3\\ 2\\ 1\end{pmatrix}@d

feedback.text: The square of the length is @i9+4+1@i, which is less than @i16@i

name.text: More equations than unknowns imples solution exists

questiontext.text: A linear system with more equations than unknowns must have a solution.

feedback.text:
This system has more equations than unknowns and has no solution.

@d\begin{array}{rcrcrcr} x &+ &y &= &1\\ & &y &= &4\\ & &y &= &3 \end{array}@d

name.text: More unknowns than equations implies solution exists

questiontext.text: A linear system with more unknowns than equations must have a solution.

feedback.text:
This system has more unknowns than equations but has no soution.

@d\begin{array}{rcrcrcrcr} x &+ &y &+ &z &+ &w &= &0\\ & &y & & & & &= &4\\ & &y & & & & &= &3 \end{array}@d

name.text: Set of fixed dimension matrices are a vector space

questiontext.text: For any positive integers @im@i and @in@i the set of @im\times n@i matrices are a vector space under the natural operations of entry-wise addition and scalar multiplication.

feedback.text: The proof is just like the one for @i3\times 3@i.

name.text: The first quadrant is a vector space

questiontext.text: The first quadrant @i\{ (x,y)\mathrel| x,y\in\mathbb{R} \}@i is a vector space under the natural operations @i(x_1,y_1)+(x_2,y_2)=(x_1+x_2,y_1+y_2)@i and @ir(x,y)=(rx,ry)@i.

feedback.text: It is not closed under scalar multiplication by @i-1@i.

name.text: The point is on the plane with given equation

questiontext.text:
The point @i(1,0,3)@i is on this plane.

@d\{ \begin{pmatrix} 3\\ 0\\ -1\end{pmatrix} +s\begin{pmatrix} -1\\ 0\\ 1\end{pmatrix} +t\begin{pmatrix} 2\\ 5\\ 1\end{pmatrix} \mathrel| s,t\in\mathbb{R} \}@d

feedback.text: Set up the linear system in variables @is@i and @it@i.

name.text: These matrices are row-equivalent

questiontext.text:
These matrices are row-equivalent

@d\begin{pmatrix} 2 &1 &-1\\ 4 &0 &2\\ 6 &3 &-3 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 2 &2 &0\\ 8 &4 &4\\ 2 &2 &1 \end{pmatrix}@d

generalfeedback.text: Check whether they yield the same echelon form.

name.text: These matrices are row-equivalent

questiontext.text:
These matrices are row-equivalent.

@d\begin{pmatrix} 1 &0 &3\\ 0 &1 &4 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 1 &0 &0\\ 0 &1 &0 \end{pmatrix}, @d

name.text: These matrices are row-equivalent.

questiontext.text:
These matrices are row-equivalent.

@i\begin{pmatrix} 2 &1\\ 3 &0 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 1 &-1\\ 1 &1 \end{pmatrix}@i

feedback.text: They have the same reduced echelon form.

name.text: These vectors are orthogonal

questiontext.text:
These vectors are orthogonal.

@d\begin{pmatrix} -3\\ -1\\ 4\end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} -1\\ 3\\ 0\end{pmatrix}@d

name.text: The vector lies on the line with given equation

questiontext.text:
The vector with endpoint @i(5,2)@i lies on the line given by this description.

@d\{ \begin{pmatrix} 3\\ -2\end{pmatrix} +t\begin{pmatrix}0.5\\ 1\end{pmatrix} \mathrel| t\in\mathbb{R} \}@d

name.text: The zero matrix is in reduced echelon form

questiontext.text: The sero matrix is in reduced echelon form.

name.text: This matrix is singular

questiontext.text:
This matrix is singular.

@d\begin{pmatrix} 2 &-1 &0\\ 0 &1 &1\\ 1 &2 &0 \end{pmatrix}@d

generalfeedback.text: Apply Gauss's Method.  If the echelon form has at least one row of all @i0@i's then the matrix is singular.  If every row in the echelon form has a leading entry then the matrix is nonsingular.

name.text: Union of two vector spaces is a vector space

questiontext.text: The union of two vector spaces is a vector space.

feedback.text: Both @i\mathbb{R}^2@i and @i\mathbb{R}^3@i are vector spaces under the natural addition and scalar multiplication operations.  But the union is not a vector space since the addition of a vector from the first with a vector from the second is not defined.
